6 Minute English from BBCLearningEnglish.com
Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English. I'm Aliceâ€¦
speaker: Alice

text: And I'm Neil. So, Alice, what's your ideal place to be?
Oh, curled up on the sofa with a good book in front of a log fire.
Last night it was very cold
speaker: Alice

text: Well, for me, lying in a hammock under a palm tree on a tropical beach,
with a cool breeze. I don't like it when it's too hot.
Hmm, yes, true. Humans don't cope well with extremes of temperature,
but some species do. The subject of today's show is extremophiles.
speaker: extremophiles

text: These are microorganisms that have adapted to live in what we would consider to be extreme conditions.
For example, living in near-boiling acidic water, or frozen at the bottom of an Antarctic lake.
Hmm, those do sound like pretty extreme conditions.
Yes, the thing is, what sounds hostile, or unfriendly to us,
speaker: hostile

text: are perfect environments for extremophiles,
and in fact, they wouldn't survive without them.
Now, are you tough enough to face up to today's quiz question, Neil?
Oh, I think so.
All right, then here goes.
Which US National Park is home to geeseers,
or hot springs that shoot hot water and steam into the air,
speaker: geysers

text: which have extremophiles living in them?
Is it a Grand Canyon,
speaker: Neil

text: b Death Valley National Park, or c Yellowstone?
speaker: geysers

text: Oh, that's easy. It has to be c Yellowstone.
Okay, well, we'll find out if you got the answer right later on in the show.
But moving on now, Neil,
speaker: Neil

text: did you know that extremophiles belong to an entirely different group of living things
to other animals and plants?
No. I imagined extremophiles would be like insects,
speaker: Neil

text: because insects are pretty tough, aren't they?
Yes, that's true.
But remember, extremophiles are microorganisms.
They're really tiny.
Let's listen to Ian Crawford,
professor of planetary science and astrobiology at Birkbeck University of London.
He tells us how in the 1970s, a scientist called Carl Wurzer
identified a new kingdom of living things that he called archaea,
meaning ancient ones.
The extremophiles belong to this group.
Well, the old tree of life idea basically talked about empires
speaker: Ian Crawford, Professor of Planetary Science and Astrobiology at Birkbeck University of London

text: if you like, of plants and animals.
And the things that we can see essentially,
we put a great deal of emphasis on large organisms
and the traditional distinction in biology between botany and zoology.
What it really did was say, that's all wrong.
There's really only three major groups in life.
There's the archaea, the bacteria,
and the eukaryotes, which is all of this complex life.
And so it kind of put humans into a small corner of the tree of life
mixed to plants and whatever else.
It kind of squashes us again out of being the center of the universe.
So botany is the study of plant life and zoology is the study of animal life.
But maybe you can explain archaea and eukaryotes, Alice.
Archaea are a group of single-celled microbes similar to bacteria
speaker: ArchaeaEukaryote

text: but different to all other known types.
Eukaryote is the scientific term for organisms with a much larger or more complex type of cell.
And this group includes all animals, plants, and fungi.
But why are archaea so important?
Why do they need a whole biological domain to themselves?
Are we humans, gets squashed up in one domain with plants and fungi?
Well, Neil, it's likely they've been living on our planet ever since the Earth became habitable,
and that's billions of years.
speaker: Alice

text: And they are still living and thriving in a whole range of different environments today.
And when something is thriving, it means it's doing well.
So tell us about where they live, Alice.
Some live in hydrothermal vents, holes in the ocean floor, hundreds of meters down,
where there's lots of pressure and no sunlight.
speaker: hydrothermal vents

text: And mineral-rich superheated water is coming out of the Earth's crust,
and then flowing out through these holes.
I see. Well, what about cold-loving extramophiles?
Well, scientists have found them in hidden lakes trapped beneath ice sheets hundreds of meters thick
in Antarctica. It takes days to drill through the ice to reach the water
speaker: Alice

text: And how do they survive down there?
Well, these microbes have found a way of getting energy from certain minerals like iron and sulfur,
present in the water
speaker: Alice

text: Hmm, that sounds clever from microbes.
How do they figure that out?
It isn't a question of cleverness - it's a question of adaptation
speaker: Alice

text: Extramophiles are extremely well adapted to their environment,
and they appeared on Earth much earlier than more complex life forms.
Let's hear from Nick Lane, reader in Evolutionary Biochemistry at University College London.
The origin of the eukaryotic cello, say it seems to have happened once,
it took about two billion years before that happened.
Then there was a kind of great leap forward at the cellular level,
but another billion years went by before we see animals.
So basically, the animal kingdom is much newer than the archaeian kingdom.
Indeed. And now it's time for the answer to today's quiz question, Neil.
I asked, which US National Park is home to geese that have extramophiles living in them?
Is it a, Grand Canyon, B, Death Valley National Park, or C, Yellowstone?
And I said c) Yellowstone. I must be right.
speaker: Neil

text: Yes, Neil, you are right. It's Yellowstone National Park.
Every year, scientists discover remarkable new microbes in Yellowstone's hot springs,
with implications for medicine, agriculture and energy,
as well as offering clues to the formation of the earliest life on Earth.
Very interesting. Now, here are the words we heard today:
speaker: Neil

text: Extramophiles, hostile, geezers, microorganisms, botany, zoology, archaea,
eukaryote, thriving, hydrothermal vents.
And that's the end of today's Sixth and It English.
Don't forget to join us again soon. Bye.
speaker: Alice

text: Bye.
